tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

Possible meanings are 1) "song people sang while going up to Jerusalem for a celebration" or 2) "song people sang while going up the steps into the temple" or 3) "song whose words are like steps." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:120:001|120:1]]

tn.ref: Blessed is everyone who honors Yahweh
tn.text: This phrase occurs in the passive voice to avoid implying that Yahweh is obligated to bless those who honor him. This can be stated in active form. AT: "Yahweh will bless everyone who honors him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
A man can be referred to by his hands because that is the part of the body he works with. AT: "What you provide" or "What you work for" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: you will be blessed and prosper
tn.text: The words "be blessed" and "prosper" share similar meanings and emphasize God's favor. AT: "Yahweh will bless you and prosper you" or "Yahweh will make you blessed and prosperous" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: like a fruitful vine in your house
tn.text: The wife is spoke of as a vine producing a lot of fruit. This implies that children are like fruit and the wife will have many children. AT: "very productive and give you many children" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: your children will be like olive plants
tn.text: Children are compared to olive plants because of the way they grow to surround something. Children will surround the table and make it full. AT: "you will have many children who will grow and prosper" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
This refers to the place where a family gathers to eat. Often, all those who eat a man's table are under his authority or control.

tn.ref: the man will be blessed who honors Yahweh
tn.text: This can be stated as an active verb. "Yahweh will bless the man who honors him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: all the days of your life
